results.title: A News Anchor Had Stroke Symptoms on Air. Her Colleagues Jumped Into Action.
results.abstract: Julie Chin, an anchor with the Tulsa, Okla., NBC affiliate KJRH, thanked her colleagues for helping her get medical attention immediately and said she was recovering.

media.caption: Julie Chin, a KJRH news anchor.

results.title: Official Obama Portraits Are Finally Unveiled at the White House
results.abstract: In a break with tradition, there was no ceremony while former President Donald J. Trump held office. President Biden unveiled the Obama portraits: his by Robert McCurdy, hers by Sharon Sprung.

results.title: Spelling Bee Forum
results.abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

results.title: Former Pentagon Leaders Warn of a Dangerous Era
results.abstract: The challenge to the 2020 election result has helped create “an extremely adverse environment,” former defense secretaries and generals said in an open letter.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: In summer 2020, General Mark A. Milley, right, was summoned by President Donald J. Trump for a walk across a park where protesters had just been tear-gassed so Mr. Trump could do a photo op holding a Bible.

results.title: Bannon to Surrender to New York Authorities to Face Sealed Indictment
results.abstract: After President Donald J. Trump pardoned him in a case connected to a crowd-funded border wall, the Manhattan district attorney’s office opened its own investigation.

media.caption: Stephen K. Bannon, pardoned by former President Donald Trump in 2021, is turning himself in.

results.byline: By Patricia Mazzei, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
results.title: Trump Ruling Lifts Profile of Judge and Raises Legal Eyebrows
results.abstract: Judge Aileen M. Cannon has issued the first highly scrutinized ruling of her short judicial career, involving the person who put her on the bench: former President Donald J. Trump.

media.caption: Judge Aileen M. Cannon granted former President Donald J. Trump’s request to appoint a special master to review materials seized from Mar-a-Lago, his private Florida club.
media.copyright: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times

results.byline: By Ian Austen, Vjosa Isai and Dan Bilefsky
results.title: Second Suspect in Saskatchewan Killings Dies After Capture
results.abstract: After a four-day manhunt, the police arrested Myles Sanderson, a suspect in a stabbing rampage that left 10 dead in the Canadian province. He was pronounced dead at a hospital after going into “medical distress,” the police said.

results.adx_keywords: United States Politics and Government;Politics and Government;Elections, Governors;Midterm Elections (2022);Abrams, Stacey Y;Kemp, Brian P;Democratic Party
results.byline: By Maya King and Reid J. Epstein
results.title: Democrats Fret as Stacey Abrams Struggles in Georgia Governor’s Race
results.abstract: She has been trailing her Republican rival, Gov. Brian Kemp, alarming Democrats who have celebrated her as the master strategist behind the state’s Democratic shift.

media.caption: Stacey Abrams has worked for years to register and turn out Democratic voters, helping to fuel victories by President Biden and two senators in the 2020 election cycle.
media.copyright: David Walter Banks for The New York Times

results.title: Nick Kyrgios’s U.S. Open Run Ends One Match After Beating the Top Seed
results.abstract: Karen Khachanov of Russia needed five sets to put Kyrgios away, 7-5, 4-6, 7-5, 6-7, 6-4. He will play Casper Ruud of Norway in the semifinals on Friday.

media.caption: Nick Kyrgios of Australia throwing his racket during his quarterfinal match against Karen Khachanov of Russia. He slammed another one after the match.

results.title: Body of Abducted Memphis Teacher Is Found, Police Say
results.abstract: Eliza Fletcher was on an early morning jog last week when she was forced into an S.U.V., the police said. A man has been charged with her murder.

media.caption: Eliza Fletcher was abducted during an early morning jog in Memphis last week.

results.title: Anne Garrels, Fearless NPR Correspondent, Dies at 71
results.abstract: She reported on conflicts around the world and for a time was the only American broadcast journalist reporting from Baghdad during the U.S. “shock and awe” bombing campaign in 2003.

media.caption: The NPR correspondent Anne Garrels in Iraq in 2006. She became known for conveying how momentous events like wars affected the people who lived through them.

results.title: The Raccoons of Central Park Move in Packs and Go Fast. On Bikes.
results.abstract: The Central Park Raccoons, a loose group of cyclists, gather after dark for impromptu races. Anything on two wheels (except electric bikes) can compete.

media.caption: The finish line at a recent late-night race in the bike lanes of Central Park.
